description:
The second season of Tiger & Bunny.

Fighting for peace — and their sponsors — the odd couple of Wild Tiger and Barnaby continue to work as superheroes. But with the number of superheroes increasing around the world, how will these two veterans fare!?

(Source: Netflix)

tags.name: Superhero
tags.description: Prominently features super-powered humans who aim to serve the greater good.

tags.name: Super Power
tags.description: Prominently features characters with special abilities that allow them to do what would normally be physically or logically impossible.

tags.name: Crime
tags.description: Centers around unlawful activities punishable by the state or other authority.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Drugs
tags.description: Prominently features the usage of drugs such as opioids, stimulants, hallucinogens etc.

tags.name: Primarily Adult Cast
tags.description: Main cast is mostly composed of characters above a high school age.

tags.name: Urban
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a city.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Twins
tags.description: Prominently features two or more siblings that were born at one birth.

tags.name: Adoption
tags.description: Features a character who has been adopted by someone who is neither of their biological parents.

tags.name: Conspiracy
tags.description: Contains one or more factions controlling or attempting to control the world from the shadows.

tags.name: Tokusatsu
tags.description: Prominently features elements that resemble special effects in Japanese live-action shows

tags.name: Henshin
tags.description: Prominently features character or costume transformations which often grant special abilities.

node.description: After having graduated from Tokyo Designer Gakuin, she joined [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/), and started off as an animator. She is noted as the first female mecha director, and one of the few female directors in the '80s alongside [Makoto Moriwaki](https://anilist.co/staff/109581/) and [Hiroko Tokita](https://anilist.co/staff/101903/).

[Official Website](http://k2r.main.jp/) | [Twitter](https://x.com/MasakazuKatsura)

Masakazu Katsura's turning point in his life was an illness for which he was bedridden, during which time he taught himself a different way to draw. Katsura entered the manga industry in his second or third year of high school, when he entered a work for the Tezuka Award to win the prize money. However, he says he did not grow up reading manga, instead he read novels and watched movies.

Video Girl Ai was made into an original video animation and has been released in North America. A live-action movie was also made of the story. The main action of the five-volume series DNA² was made into an anime television show that did not sell well enough to finish, so the story was concluded with a short OVA, which was also released in North America. I"s was made into at least two OVAs: one two-episode side story, and one six-episode summary of the manga.

Katsura also performed as a vocalist on the songs "Tomorrow Will Be Tomorrow" and "Unseen Dream" from the two soundtracks for the Video Girl Ai OVA.

In 2008, he collaborated with Akira Toriyama, his good friend and creator of Dragon Ball and Dr. Slump, for the Jump SQ one-shot Sachie-chan Good!!. The two became friends in the early 1980s, having been introduced by their mutual editor Kazuhiko Torishima, and have even parodied each other in their own manga. Toriyama credits Katsura with coming up with the idea to have two characters "fuse" together in Dragon Ball, leading to the Fusion technique. However, Katsura says this is only a rumor; while he did in fact suggest it to him, he knows that Toriyama was not listening and claims Toriyama later thought it up on his own.They worked together again in 2009, for the three-chapter one-shot Jiya in Weekly Young Jump.

Also in 2008, Katsura did a design illustration of the Batman costume for Bandai's "Movie Realization" action figure line, basing it on the costume used in the film The Dark Knight.

__Notable works outside anime:__

- Love & Destroy (Video Game, 1999) (Character Design)
- Astral Chain (Video Game, 2019) (Character Design)

[Official Website](http://k2r.main.jp/) | [Twitter](https://x.com/MasakazuKatsura)

name.native: ユニゾン・スクエア・ガーデン

node.description: Website | Twitter Unison Square Garden, stylized as UNISON SQUARE GARDEN, is a 3 member boy band under the record label TOY'S FACTORY (formerly under UK PROJECT). Members: - Kousuke Saitou (斎藤宏介) (Vocal & Guitar) - [Tomoya Tabuchi](https://anilist.co/staff/148232/Tomoya-Tabuchi) (田淵智也) (Vocal & Bass) - Takao Suzuki (鈴木貴雄) (Vocal & Drums) (Source: jpop.fandom.com)

[Website](https://ano-official.com/) | [Twitter](https://twitter.com/ano2mass) | [Instagram](https://www.instagram.com/a_n_o2mass/) | [TikTok](https://www.tiktok.com/@anovamos)

ano is a Japanese singer, model, actor, and TV personality. She was a member of the idol group You'll Melt More! (ゆるめるモ!) from 2013-2019. In 2020, she started solo activities under the name "ano". In 2021, she formed the band "I's" with Takuya Nakayama (from Goodbye Fujiyama), Ryuki Maeda (from ALL CITY STEPPERS) and Ryouta Unebasami (from SUNNY CAR WASH) where she performs guitar and vocals.

She played [Momoko Touyoko](https://anilist.co/character/23036) in the TV drama and live-action movie adaptations of the manga [Saki](https://anilist.co/manga/36310/Saki/).
